Remediation of lead contaminated soil by biochar-supported nano-hydroxyapatite
Zhangmei Yang a,b, Zhanqiang Fang a,b,n, Liuchun Zheng a,b, Wen Cheng a,b, Pokeung Eric Tsang b,c, Jianzhang Fang a,b, Dongye Zhao d

Keywords: Lead contaminated soil nHAP@BC Soil properties Bioavailability Accumulation Translocation

a b s t r a c t
In this study, a high efficiency and low cost biochar-supported nano-hydroxyapatite (nHAP@BC) material was used in the remediation of lead (Pb)-contaminated soil. The remediation effect of nHAP@BC on Pbcontaminated soil was evaluated through batch experiments. The stability, bioaccessibility of Pb in the soil and the change in soil characteristics are discussed. Furthermore, the effects of the amendments on the growth of cabbage mustard seedlings and the accumulation of Pb were studied. The results showed that the immobilization rates of Pb in the soil were 71.9% and 56.8%, respectively, after a 28 day remediation using 8% nHAP and nHAP@BC materials, and the unit immobilization amount of nHAP@BC was 5.6 times that of nHAP, indicating that nHAP@BC can greatly reduce the cost of remediation of Pb in soil. After the nHAP@BC remediation, the residual fraction Pb increased by 61.4%, which greatly reduced the bioaccessibility of Pb in the soil. Moreover, nHAP@BC could effectively reduce the accumulation of Pb in plants by 31.4%. Overall, nHAP@BC can effectively remediate Pb-contaminated soil and accelerate the recovery of soil fertility.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The survey of Chinese soil pollution bulletin in 2014 showed that the overall national soil exceeding rate was 16.1%. The exceeding rate of farmland and the point exceeding rate of lead (Pb) were 19.4% and 1.5%, respectively (Singh et al., 2003; Teng et al., 2014). Pb contamination of soil is very serious. The development of green, efficient and economic soil remediation technologies are urgently needed.
Nano-hydroxyapatite (nHAP) has been widely used in the immobilization of heavy metals for its large specific surface area, high stability under reducing and oxidizing conditions and its high sorption capacity for heavy metals (He et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2014a, 2014b). The main remediation mechanism of Pb in soil by nHAP was dissolution-precipitation. This process causes the formation of pyromorphite, which has a lower solubility, reducing the bioavailability of Pb (Li et al., 2014). However, the application of nHAP has negative effects on the soil environment, such as
d Environment, South China
reducing the organic matter content in soil and causing an imbalance in the nutrient elements. Moreover, nHAP are not mobile in soils, which prevents solid phosphate from being delivered to the Pb affected zone and from the effective remediation of Pb in the deep soil. Biochar (BC) has recently been used as a support to disperse and stabilize nanoparticles, enhancing their environmental application.
Biochar is an organic carbon-rich material produced via pyrolysis of agricultural wastes, in an oxygen-limited environment (Gaunt and Lehmann, 2008). Recent studies have highlighted BC's role in improving the physical and chemical properties of soil and immobilizing heavy metals (Beesley et al., 2011, 2010; Wu et al., 2012), attributed to its large specific surface area and porous structure, generally high pH and active functional groups. On the one hand, it can reduce the agglomeration of nHAP, thus improving its mobility. On the other hand, it can absorb phosphorus, preventing excessive phosphorus leaching into underground water and causing secondary pollution. Typically, the composite material can improve soil fertility and decrease the mobility and bioavailability of heavy metals. Zhou et al. (2014) studied the removal efficiency of BC-supported zero-valent iron for heavy metal ions in aqueous solution. The results showed that BC-modified iron has an excellent ability to remove heavy metals. The removal
rate of Pb in aqueous solution was more than 93%. Wang et al. (2015) used BC-modified hematite to remove arsenic (As) from aqueous solution, which not only had more sorption sites but also showed a greater ability to remove As, with a maximal adsorption capacity of 429 mg/kg. At present, BC-modified materials are often used for the removal of heavy metals in aqueous solution, however, it is rarely used for soil remediation.
In this paper, a BC-supported nHAP (nHAP@BC) material was prepared and used for the remediation of Pb-contaminated soil, to avoid the negative effects of hydroxyapatite on soil remediation and improve soil fertility, achieving a green, efficient, economical soil remediation technology. The research contents of this study are, (1) the preparation and characterization of nHAP@BC, (2) remediation of Pb-contaminated soil, (3) remediation mechanisms and (4) toxicity evaluation of plant seedling growth.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: All chemicals used in this study were analytical grade. The soil sample was collected from the Higher Education Mega Center in Guangzhou, China. The soil was sieved with a 2 mm standard sieve after air-drying and stored in a dryer. The physicochemical characteristics of the soil are shown in Table 1. Cabbage mustard seeds were purchased from the Vegetable Research Institute at the Guangdong Academy of Agriculture Sciences (Guangzhou, China).

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation and characterization of materials
sections.text:
Pb-spiked soil samples were prepared using the following procedure. The raw soil was mixed with a Pb(NO3)2 solution at a soil-to-solution ratio of 1:5, then stirred for 24 h, which has been proven experimentally to be a sufficient time to reach equilibrium conditions. The soil suspension was centrifuged and the supernatant was decanted. The remaining soil was washed twice with deionized water, to remove any traces of the soluble Pb(Ⅱ) spike. The decanted supernatant and rinse water were filtered through a 0.22 mm membrane filter, and the concentration of Pb(Ⅱ) in the filtrate was analyzed. The Pb concentration of remaining soil was tested by acid digestion. The Pb uptake by the soil was calculated by comparing the initial and final concentration of Pb in the aqueous phase. The resultant Pb concentration in the soil was 640.5 mg/kg. The Pb-loaded soil was then air-dried for future use.
BC was produced by pyrolysis of bagasse (Jiang et al., 2012a, 2012b; Ding et al., 2014). The bagasse was oven-dried at 105 °C and used to tightly fill ceramic crucibles. The materials with the ceramic crucibles were then placed in a muffle furnace to pyrolyze under oxygen-limited conditions. The pyrolysis temperature was raised to 600 °C at a rate of approximately 10 °C per min and kept constant for 2 h. The BC was then allowed to cool to room temperature inside the muffle furnace. All BCs were taken out and then ground, to examine their characteristics without further treatment.
The nHAP@BC was prepared as follows. A given quantity of
nHAP particles were dispersed in the solution for 30 min, followed by the addition of KCl and bagasse. The mixture was then stirred for 30 min and oven-dried at 80 °C for 8 h after the separation (Wang et al., 2015; Yao et al., 2014). The following steps were in accordance with the preparation method of BC.
The surface morphology of the materials was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, NoVaTMNano430). The specific surface area was measured by nitrogen adsorption isotherm using a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface analyzer (BET, ASAP2020M, Micro-meritics Instrument Corp, USA). A Fourier transform infrared spectrometer was used to analyze the types of surface functional groups of the materials (IRPrestige21). X-ray diffraction (XRD) were performed by using Cu Kα radiation (D8 Advance, Bruker Corporation, German).

sections.heading: 2.3. Remediation experiment
sections.text: For the determination of optimal repair time, the remediation experiments were performed with 2 g of soil at a soil-to-solution ratio of 1:4. The soil samples were amended with 10% (w/w) BC, 8% nHAP and 8% nHAP@BC, and the mixtures were placed in a shaker to react for 1, 3, 7, 14, 28 and 42 days. For the determination of the optimum dosage, the dosages of BC were 1%, 5%, 10% and 20% respectively, and the dosages were 1%, 5%, 8% and 10% for nHAP and nHAP@BC. The soil-to-solution ratio was 1:4. The samples were placed into a shaker to react for an optimal repair time. Pb-spiked soil without amendment treatment was used as the control sample. Three replicates were used. The GBT 23739- 2009 method was used to extract the available Pb from the soils. The Pb content of the soils was determined by flame atomic absorption spectrophotometry.

sections.heading: 2.4. Chemical stability of Pb in soil after remediation
sections.text: To estimate the in vitro bioaccessibility of soil-bound Pb for humans, a biochemically-oriented method, PBET (Kelley et al., 2002), was used, which compares the leachability of Pb in the soil before and after the amendment treatment. Moreover, a sequential extraction procedure (SEP) was used to quantify the fraction of the various Pb species (Tessier et al., 1979; Reddy et al., 2001). All of the tests were duplicated to ensure data quality.

sections.heading: 2.5. Soil characteristics after remediation
sections.text: To analyze the effect of amendment on the soil characteristics and to further discuss the repair mechanism, soil pH, organic matter (OM) and available phosphorus content (A-P) were determined. The soil pH was evaluated by potentiometry. The potassium dichromate method was used to analyze the change in the soil organic matter content before and after remediation. The content of A-P in the soil was determined using the sodium bicarbonate extraction Mo-Sb anti-spectrophotometry method.

sections.heading: 2.6. Plant growth experiment
sections.text:
According to the research of Wang et al. (2014a, 2014b), uncontaminated soil (S0), Pb-contaminated soil (S1), BC-amended soil (S2), nHAP-amended soil (S3) and nHAP@BC-amended soil (S4) were investigated, to estimate the accumulation of Pb and the effects of the amendments on the growth of cabbage mustard seedlings. The plant growth experiments were conducted in a set of 120 mm culture dishes covered with double-layer filter papers. Each of dishes received 5 g of soil sample and 25 mL deionized water. Then, 15 seeds were placed inside each dish and placed in a growth chamber (GP-01, Huangshi Hengfeng Med-ical Instrument Co., Ltd, China) with day and night temperatures of 25 °C (1700 lx,
16 h) and 20 °C (8 h), respectively. Three replicates were employed. During plants growth, seeds germination was recorded and they were watered with deionized water daily to maintain the original moisture. After 10 days, the seedlings were harvested and washed thoroughly with deionized water. The clean plant samples were then separated into three parts (roots, stems and leaves) and the length of each part was measured. Then, the separated plant samples were dried in an oven at 80 °C for 48 h and the weights of the dried tissues were recorded. The dried samples were ashed in a muffle furnace at 550 °C for 6 h and then digested by nitric acid. Finally, the digested samples were analyzed for the total Pb content by flame atomic-absorption spectrophotometer.

sections.heading: 2.7. Statistical analysis
sections.text: A one-way ANOVA, followed by a Student-Newman-Keuls (SNK) multiple comparison test (po0.05), was used to determine the significant differences between the groups. Prior to ANOVA, normality of data (Shapiro- Wilk test) and equal variance (Levene's test) were tested.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of amendments
sections.text:
The pore structure and the surface morphology were
Fig. 1. (a) SEM image of the BC. (b
determined visually by SEM. Fig. 1a shows that the BC had a honeycomb, porous structure, which was conducive to the adsorption of heavy metals (Lehmann and Joseph, 2001). The SEM image of nHAP@BC had a lot of white particles (Fig. 1b), which turned out to be the nHAP dispersed on the surface and within the pores of the BC. The BET surface area of the BC and nHAP were 77.57 and 55.22 m2/g. The specific surface area of nHAP@BC was 59.73 m2/g and larger than that of nHAP. This could be due to the decomposition of the organic matter in the BC and the formation of microporous structures at the higher pyrolysis temperature (Katyal et al., 2003).
The FTIR spectra of materials are shown in Fig. 2. A number of adsorption peaks were observed in the BC (Qiu et al., 2008). The peak at 753 cm 1 was assigned to the –CH2 stretching, while the peak at 1112 cm 1 was related to C–O stretching of the –OCH3 group, which was attributed to the lignin structure in bagasse. The absorption bands at 2162 and 3045 cm 1 were the C–H group. The absorption peak of the nHAP@BC was similar to that of the nHAP. The peak at 962 cm 1 was due to the bending vibration of the P–O bond. The symmetric sorption band at 1025 cm 1 was the PO43 group. The peak at about 1410 cm 1 was the stretching vibration absorption peak of CO32 or –COO, while that at 3242 cm 1 was attributed to the –OH stretching. Compared to the nHAP, the nHAP@BC had more peaks, with peaks appearing at 1574 cm 1 (C¼O) and 2161 cm 1 (C–H). The peak at 880–828 cm 1 could be the band of C–Cl or C–H. These indicated the existence of the nHAP's characteristic peaks and it could be inferred that the nHAP
) SEM image of the nHAP@BC.
had successfully loaded onto the BC. The presence of these functional groups can increase the complexation and precipitation reaction of Pb (II) in the soil (Liu and Zhao, 2013).
Fig. 3 presents XRD patterns of nHAP and nHAP@BC which both were similar to each other. Eight characteristic peaks for nHAP appeared in the pattern, which were consistent with the database (JCPDS standard no. 01-072-1243). Furthermore, these characteristic peaks was still observed in the pattern for nHAP@BC, and the intensity of characteristic peaks were weakened. It indicated that the nHAP was dispersed within the pores of BC in the nHAP@BC particles.

sections.heading: 3.2. Remediation effect of amendments for Pb
3.2.1. Effects of remediation time on Pb immobilization
sections.text:
The immobilization effects of the three kinds of materials were enhanced with the increase of the remediation time (Fig. 4). When the time was 1 day, the immobilization rates of the BC, nHAP and nHAP@BC for Pb in the soil were 18.4%, 57.4% and 44.2%, respectively. When the remediation time was 7 days, the immobilization rates increased to 20.5%, 65% and 49.9%. When the time was 28 days, the rates of the BC, nHAP and nHAP@BC were 31.4%, 71.9% and 56.8%, respectively, an increase of 13%, 14.5% and 12.6% compared with a remediation time of 1 day. When the remediation time was increased from 28 days to 42 days, the immobilization
rates of Pb for the BC and nHAP@BC increased slightly. In conclusion, the optimal remediation time was 28 days.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Effects of dosage on Pb immobilization
sections.text: Fig. 5 shows that the immobilization rates of Pb increased as the material dosages were increased after a 28 days remediation. When the BC dosage was increased from 1% to 5%, the rate was enhanced from 9.1% to 15.3%. When the dosage was increased from 5% to 10%, the rate increased by 16.1%. When the BC dosage was increased to 20%, the rate increased by 8%. Taking both effectiveness and cost into consideration, 10% BC was chosen as the optimal dosage. Similarly, when the dosages of the nHAP and nHAP@BC were increased from 1% to 8%, the rates rose, increasing from 45.3% and 24% to 71.9% and 59.4%, respectively. When the dosage was increased from 8% to 10%, the rate tended to be constant, so the optimum dosage of the nHAP and the nHAP@BC was 8%.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Comparison of unit immobilization amount of Pb
sections.text:
In order to further compare the remediation effect of the nHAP and nHAP@BC, the unit immobilization amount was used. The unit immobilization amount of Pb, which refers to the immobilization amount of Pb per gram of the nHAP, was denoted as mg/g-nHAP. As shown in Fig. 6, when the dosage was 1%, the unit immobilization amounts of the nHAP and nHAP@BC were 16.96 and 98.79 mg/g-nHAP, and the unit immobilization amount of
nHAP@BC was 5.8 times that of nHAP. When the dosages were 5% and 8%, the unit immobilization quantities of the nHAP@BC were 5.5 and 5.6 times that of the nHAP, respectively. This indicated that the immobilization capacity of the nHAP@BC for Pb was greater than that of the nHAP, which would greatly reduce the cost of remediation of Pb in soil.

sections.heading: 3.3. Bioaccessibility and speciation of soil Pb
3.3.1. PBET
sections.text: The bioaccessibility of Pb in the soil before and after remediation was investigated. Table 2 shows that the bioaccessibility of Pb in S1, S2, S3 and S4 was 65.1%, 55.3%, 48.2% and 52.1%, respectively. Compared to S1, the bioaccessibility of Pb in S2, S3 and S4 decreased by 9.8%, 16.9% and 13.0%. This suggested that the BC, nHAP and nHAP@BC could reduce the bioaccessibility of Pb in the soil, reducing the toxicity to living organisms. According to the research of Buatier et al. (2001), Pb2þ is usually absorbed by iron oxides, organic matter and clay mineral in acidic soil, and even exists in the form of pyromorphite. The bioaccessibility of these forms is lower than that of carbonate-bound Pb. It can be speculated that the exchangeable fraction and the carbonate-bound fraction of Pb could be transformed into lower bioaccessibility species, such as Fe–Mn oxide-bound and residual after the remediation with the nHAP and nHAP@BC, thus reducing the toxicity of Pb in the soil.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. SEP
sections.text:
According to the sequential extraction method of Tessier, the total content of soil-bound Pb was separated into five defined fractions, exchangeable (EX), carbonate-bound (CB), Fe–Mn oxidebound (OX), organic matter-bound (OM) and residual (RS). Fig. 7 illustrates that the primary Pb species in S1 soil were CB (40.7%) and OX (43.4%), whereas the content of EX (9.7%), OM (1.0%) and RS (4.4%) were less in this untreated soil.
Compared to the S1, the EX and CB fractions in S2 were converted to OX and RS, which increased by 5.8% and 5.1%, respectively. This could be due to the BC can improve the soil pH and
generate hydroxide precipitation, thus causing the increase in OX. Another reason is that the BC has rich oxygen-containing functional groups, which can complex with Pb to the organic-bound Pb. A large number of studies have shown that BC can affect the morphology and migration of heavy metals in the soil, allowing easy migration of the heavy metal fraction into the weak mobility fractions, such as OM and RS, solidifying the heavy metal and reducing its bioavailability (Jiang et al., 2012a, 2012b). Compared to S1, the EX, CB and OX fractions in S3 were significantly reduced by 8.1%, 35.7% and 30.1%, respectively, while the RS proportion increased by 75.5%, greatly reducing the bioavailability of Pb. According to previous investigations (Buatier et al., 2001), the elevated RS fraction might be largely attributed to the precipitation of Pb3(PO4)2 or pyromorphite during the nHAP treatment. The influence of the nHAP@BC on the soil-bound Pb was similar to that of the nHAP. After the nHAP@BC remediation, the proportions of EX, CB and OX in S4 decreased by 9.03%, 27.5% and 24.7%, respectively, compared with S1, which was the reason for the increase in the RS fraction (61.4%). This distinctive alteration in Pb speciation, in particular the substantial increase in the RS fraction, accounted for the reduced bioavailability of Pb in the previous study. Overall, the nHAP@BC can promote the conversion of more easily available Pb (EX, CB) to the unavailable RS fraction, thus reducing its toxic effect.

sections.heading: 3.4. Influence of amendments on soil properties
sections.text:
Table 3 shows the soil properties after the remediation by the BC, nHAP and nHAP@BC. The soil pH is an important factor influencing the biological effectiveness of heavy metals, with changes in pH leading to variation in their speciation. Compared with S1, the soil pH of S2, S3 and S4 increased by 0.38, 0.71 and 0.96, respectively. The pH of the nHAP@BC-amended soil increased greatly, demonstrating that the composite of BC and nHAP can further improve the soil pH and is helpful to the precipitation reaction of Pb.
The effect of the nHAP@BC on the increase in the soil pH is due both to the role of alkaline substances, such as carbonates and

sections.heading: S2 0.144 0.096
sections.text:
oxides (calcium oxide and magnesium oxide, etc.), in the BC and to the hydrolysis and precipitation reaction of the nHAP. BC can increase the soil pH by promoting the exchange reaction of alkali ions. Yao et al. (2011) found that BC made of bagasse contains many calcium and magnesium compounds, which can generate mineral crystallisation on the surface of BC, thus improving the soil pH. Xu et al. (2013) reported that after adding 10% BC to soil, the soil pH rose from 3.83 to 7.91. The role of nHAP in soil pH was attributed to the fact that the dissolution of HAP in the soil solution can consume Hþ , resulting in an increase in the soil pH (Cui et al., 2013).
Soil organic matter is an important indicator in measuring soil nutrients. In this experiment, the soil organic matter content increased from 31.10 g/kg in S1 to 65.99 g/kg after the nHAP@BC remediation. However, it was just 26.55 g/kg after the nHAP remediation, reduced by 4.55 g/kg in S3 compared to S1. The results proved that the nHAP@BC could significantly increase the soil organic matter content. The application of BC is beneficial to the accumulation and formation of soil organic matter (Kimetu and Lehmann, 2010), and has important significance in improving the soil fertility and the balance of the soil organic carbon pool. The nHAP can react with amino acids, proteins and organic acids, resulting in a decrease in the organic matter. The composite material, nHAP@BC, can increase the soil organic matter, making up for the shortage of nHAP, and accelerating the recovery of the soil fertility simultaneously with the remediation of heavy metals.
BC contains large amounts of phosphorus, up to 2773 mg/kg, and can increase soil phosphorus directly (Topoliantz et al., 2005). nHAP has a lot of phosphate ions and can generate phosphates when it hydrolyses in soil solution, improving the soil phosphorus content. However, too much phosphorus precipitation in groundwater can cause eutrophication of the water environment. As shown in Table 3, the available P increased from 6.28 to 18.73, 107.67 and 60.97 mg/kg after the remediation of BC, HAP and nHAP@BC respectively. According to the second soil census and the related standards, the available P content could be improved to Level 1 in nHAP- and nHAP@BC-amended soils. Compared with the nHAP, the nHAP@BC could decrease the available P from 107.67 mg/kg to 60.97 mg/kg, which showed that nHAP@BC could increase the available P content, while avoiding the excessive release of phosphorus.

sections.heading: 3.5.1. Effects on plant seedling growth
sections.text: To determine the effect of the amended soil on plant growth, some toxicological endpoints such as seed germination percentage, seedling growth and biomass production were measured during the cultivation. The results showed that the effect on cabbage mustard seed germination rate of different soils was not obvious, which indicated that Pb-contaminated soil, and remediation with BC, nHAP and nHAP@BC, had no significant effect on the germination rate. As shown in Fig. 8, the root lengths of cabbage mustard in S0, S1, S2, S3 and S4 were 41, 46, 49, 34 and 43 mm, while the shoot lengths were 45, 42, 46, 38 and 44 mm, respectively. Compared with S0, S1 promoted the growth of seedling roots slightly. However, the shoot growth was inhibited, showing that Pb was toxic for cabbage mustard seedling growth. S2 had a significant promoting effect on the seedling root growth. S3 inhibited the seedling growth significantly, and the seedling root and shoot length both decreased by 7 mm. Compared with S3, the seedling root and shoot lengths in S4 increased by 24.4% and 16.1%, respectively. This suggested that the nHAP@BC could reduce the inhibiting effect of the nHAP on the seedling growth, but could also gradually restore the soil quality, which could be useful for the cultivation.

sections.heading: 3.5.2. Accumulation and translocation of Pb
sections.text:
To further validate the immobilization efficiency of the amendments to soil Pb, we compared the accumulation and translocation of Pb for plants grown in different soils. Table 4 shows that the three kinds of amendments reduced the Pb content in plant tissues to different degrees. In addition, the reduction of Pb accumulation in the stem and leaf was most remarkable. There was no Pb in the plant of S0. The Pb content in the root, stem and leaf for S1 was 817.5, 236.6 and 100.1 mg/kg, respectively. Compared with S1, the Pb levels in the root, stem and leaf for S2 decreased by 11.7%, 54.0% and 58.5%, respectively. The reduction in Pb in all tissues for S3 was significantly reduced, ranging from 817.5, 236.6 and 100.1 mg/kg to 265.4, 17.0 and 13.4 mg/kg (reduced by 67.5%, 92.8% and 86.6%). A remarkable decrease in Pb in S4 was also observed. The reduction rates for the root, stem and leaf were 62.3%, 87.1% and 76.6%, respectively. The results indicated that the nHAP@BC could effectively reduce the accumulation of Pb in plants, subsequently reducing its phytotoxicity. The remediation by the nHAP@BC was feasible for Pb-contaminated soil.
To better understand the effect of the nHAP@BC remediation on the translocation capability of Pb for cabbage mustard, the concentration factor (CF) and transfer factor (TF) were calculated (Table 5). The CF was defined as the ratio of the Pb in the aboveground parts of the plants to that in the soils, which refers to the
accumulation capacity of heavy metals in the soil-plant system. The TF refers to the ratio of Pb in the aboveground parts of the plants to that in the roots, indicating the translocation ability of heavy metals from the root to the aboveground parts. The CF and TF in S1 were 0.203 and 0.159, respectively. Compared to S1, they were reduced by 29.1% and 39.6% in S2. The CF and TF in S3 both decreased significantly, reduced by 60.1% and 65.4%, respectively, compared with S1. The CF and TF in S4 were 0.108 and 0.097, a reduction of 46.8% and 39.0%, respectively, compared to S1. Table 5 shows that the CF was greater than the TF in cabbage mustard. The migration ability of Pb from the soil to the plant root was greater than that from the root to the aboveground part of plant. This was in agreement with the result showing that the reduction in the amount of Pb in the root was lower than in the aboveground parts after the remediation. The results suggested that the CF and TF decreased notably after remediation, which proved the effectiveness of the nHAP@BC for the remediation of Pb-contaminated soil.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In the present study, we demonstrated that applying nHAP@BC to Pb-contaminated soil could enhance Pb immobilization and greatly reduce the cost of remediation. Meanwhile, nHAP@BC could promote the conversion of more easily available Pb (EX, CB) to the unavailable RS fraction, which significantly decreased the mobility and bioaccessibility of Pb in the soil. Moreover, the nHAP@BC could effectively reduce the accumulation of Pb in plants. In particular, the remediation of Pb-contaminated soil with nHAP@BC, not only improves the soil fertility for its reuse in planting, but also avoids the excessive release of phosphorus. Therefore, remediation using nHAP@BC is feasible for Pb-contaminated soil.

metadata.abstractText: In this study, a high efficiency and low cost biochar-supported nano-hydroxyapatite (nHAP@BC) material was used in the remediation of lead (Pb)-contaminated soil. The remediation effect of nHAP@BC on Pbcontaminated soil was evaluated through batch experiments. The stability, bioaccessibility of Pb in the soil and the change in soil characteristics are discussed. Furthermore, the effects of the amendments on the growth of cabbage mustard seedlings and the accumulation of Pb were studied. The results showed that the immobilization rates of Pb in the soil were 71.9% and 56.8%, respectively, after a 28 day remediation using 8% nHAP and nHAP@BC materials, and the unit immobilization amount of nHAP@BC was 5.6 times that of nHAP, indicating that nHAP@BC can greatly reduce the cost of remediation of Pb in soil. After the nHAP@BC remediation, the residual fraction Pb increased by 61.4%, which greatly reduced the bioaccessibility of Pb in the soil. Moreover, nHAP@BC could effectively reduce the accumulation of Pb in plants by 31.4%. Overall, nHAP@BC can effectively remediate Pb-contaminated soil and accelerate the recovery of soil fertility. & 2016 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
